conbody.p:
TCP ServerTCP modesThe TCP Server origin can process NetFlow messages, syslog messages, and supported data formats that are separated by specific characters.
NetFlow messages The TCP Server origin can process Netflow Version 5 messages. The origin processes flow records based on information in the packet header. So it expects multiple packets with header and flow records sent on the same connection, with no bytes in between. As a result, when processing NetFlow messages, you have no data-related properties to configure. To process NetFlow messages, set the TCP Mode property to NetFlow.
syslog messages The TCP Server origin processes syslog messages in accordance with RFC 6587, except the origin does not support method changes. The TCP Server origin can process the following types of syslog messages:
To process syslog messages, set the TCP Mode property to "syslog" and configure the transfer framing mode. All TCP clients must use the same transfer framing mode to transmit data. Use one of the following transfer framing modes:
Octet counting - The frame indicates the length of the syslog message and includes the entire contents of the message.
Non-transparent framing - The frame includes the syslog message and a user-defined trailing separator characters. The origin uses the separator characters to create records.
Use the following Java Unicode syntax to specify a separator character: \u<Unicode character code>
To define multiple characters, simply list them as a group as appropriate, such as:\u<Unicode character code>\u<Unicode character code>\u<Unicode character code>
For example, the default separator character is line feed, whose Unicode character code is 000A. To specify this as the separator character, enter \u000A.
separated records The TCP Server origin can process the supported data formats that are separated by the specified record separator characters. To process supported data formats, set the TCP Mode property to Separated Records and specify the record separator characters. Then, configure any data format-related properties.All TCP clients must use the same record separator characters.
